_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: General industry guidelines published by aqua-ammonia vendors.
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terroris
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of aqueous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  Equipment included under this covered process is a single 14,000-gallon stationary storage tank and ancillary piping and valves.



Helena receives aqueous ammonia by a vendor that transports the aqueous ammonia with a 9,600-gallon commercial tanker truck. The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the aqueous ammonia is transferred to the on-site storage tank. The transfer process from the commercial truck is performed by the commercial tanker truck operator (Vendor/Contractor). Helena does not own or operate the commercial tanker truck. The vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation and training procedures and documentation. At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its?

OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan and RMPr for review upon request by the Vendor.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: General industry guidelines published by aqua-ammonia vendors.
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Blending of aqueous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response. Equipment items included under this covered process are a single 14,000-gallon stationary storage tank and ancillary pump, piping and valves, a blending tank, and a heat exchanger.



Helena transfers aqueous ammonia from the 14,000 gallon storage tank to the blender where it is mixed with other ingredients.  The resulting fertilizer solution (which is not a covered chemical) is cooled with a non-contact heat exchanger before being sent to a storage tank.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Failure to maintain water and acid flow to the process, vehicle strike, vandalism, theft, terrorism.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the Blending of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other trained Helena staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment included under this covered process includes a 9,600-gallon commercial tanker truck, a mobile pipe reactor, and ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  An Independent Contractor operations the process and is responsible for training its personnel and managing the anhydrous ammonia in accordance with its PSM/RMPr.



Helena receives anhydrous ammonia by a vendor that transports the anhydrous ammonia with a 9,600-gallon commercial tanker truck. The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the mobile pipe reactor. The transfer process from the commercial truck is performed by the Independent Fertilizer Contractor.  In the future the blending process may be conducted by connecting to a railcar.



The commercial truck vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation for the commercial truck.  At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that its OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan to its commercial truck vendor for review and a copy of its RMPr Document upon request.



The Independent Fertilizer Contractor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation for the fertilizer blending process.  At a minimum, the Independent Fertilizer Contractor must certify that it as in place a current PSM that includes Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: 49 CFR Part 179, Specifications for Tank Cars
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: No AA railcars have been received to date.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Railcar Storage of anhydrous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  Equipment included under this covered process is a single anhydrous ammonia railcar and ancillary valves.



Helena may receive anhydrous ammonia by railcar. The railcar is temporarily parked on the Facility property it is connected to a mobile pipe reactor.  The transfer process from the railcar is performed by Independent Fertilizer Contractor (see Prevention Program for Covered Process 3).  Helena does not own or operate the railcar. The anhydrous ammonia vendor is responsible to Helena and the Department of Transportation (DOT) for providing railcars that meet DOT standards.  Helena inspects the railcars and their markings to ensure that they are within their operating window and are not leaking when they arrive onsite.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    INTRODUCTION



The Helena Chemical Company (Helena) Pasco, WA Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68.  These standards are applicable to all three of the processes described in this RMP.



Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.111 and 119 are applicable to one of the operations at this facility because the facility may use a contractor to blend fertilizers using anhydrous ammonia above the threshold quantity as one of the raw ingredients.



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia from the Facility which is located approximately 2 miles north of the City of Pasco.  The physical address to the Facility is 1010 Kartchner, Pasco, WA 99301.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



B.    PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena is submitting this RMP as part of a 5-year resubmission.  All relevant sections for the Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).  Specifically, the RMP is being updated as part of the standard 5-year resubmission and to anticipate a possible increase in the quantity of aqueous ammonia stored in an onsite tank to support a fertilizer blending process.



C.    FACILITY



The Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and that potentially operates three (4) covered processes that include (1) Storage and Handling of Aqueous Ammoni

a, (2) Fertilizer Blending with Aqueous Ammonia, (3) Fertilizer Blending with Anhydrous Ammonia by an Independent Fertilizer Contractor, and (4) Railcar Storage of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Aqueous ammonia (24.3% by weight) is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck (9,600 gallon) and then transferred into a single 14,000-gallon stationary storage tank.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Vendor/Contractor) performs the load-in transfer operation.  The aqueous ammonia is primarily used to make fertilizer blends in an onsite stationary blender operated by Helena personnel.   Anhydrous ammonia is also transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck (9,600 gallon) where it is connected to a blender by an Independent Contractor to make fertilizer products.  The Railcar Storage of anhydrous ammonia is included as a prospective process.



D.    OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the three covered processes at the facility.  



D.1    PROCESS 1



Process 1 is the storage and handling of aqueous ammonia (AqA).  The worst case scenario release assumes that all the contents at the administrative capacity of the 14,000 gallon storage tank are released.  The release was assumed to occur instantaneously and fill the surface area of the diked containment.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the AqA Storage and Handling process as well.  The alternative release for the AqA Storage and Handling process assumes that a hose break occurs during transfer operations and fills the surface of the loading pad instantaneously.



D.2    PROCESS 2



Process 2 is the blending of AqA with other ingredients to make fertilizer products.  The worst case scenario release assumes that all the contents at the administrative capacity of the 14,000 gallon storage tank are released.  The release was assumed to occur instantaneously and fill the surface area of the diked containm

ent.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the aqueous ammonia blending process as well.  The alternative release for the AqA Blending process assumes that a pipe break occurs during transfer operations and spills 760 gallons of AqA inside the containment area.



D.3    PROCESS 3



Process 3 is the blending of anhydrous ammonia (AA) with other ingredients to make fertilizer blends.  The worst case scenario release assumes that all the contents at the administrative capacity of a 34,000 gallon railcar are released even though it is expected that most of the time the blender will be connected to a 9,600 gallon commercial tanker truck.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the AA Blending process as well.  The alternative release for the AA Blending process assumes a 2-minute release from a ruptured 3-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during the blending process.



It should be noted for all of the alternative scenarios that although these events are classified as an alternative scenarios, even these accident are unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment and operating procedures that Helena and its contractors use to safeguard ammonia operations.



D.4    PROCESS 4



Process 4 is the onsite storage of anhydrous ammonia in a railcar.  The worst case  release scenario assumes that all the contents at the administrative capacity of a 34,000 gallon railcar are released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the AA Railcar Storage process as well.  The a

lternative release for the AA Railcar Storage process assumes a 60-minute release from a railcar vapor valve.



E.    ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



F.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Helena's Pasco, WA Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



G.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Facility.



H.    CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Pasco, WA Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Franklin County LEPC and the local Fire Department.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Pasco, WA Facility at this time.
